subject: Re: [junit] Need Help in Getting Started
msgSnippet: ... I don t like this class name. Call it what it is, and not some abbreviation. Also, you should consider putting Test at the end of the class name. ...
messageBody:
Waani Toss wrote:

> package junit.samples;
> import junit.framework.*;
> import java.util.*;
>
> class ser extends TestCase {

I don't like this class name. Call it what it is, and not some
abbreviation. Also, you should consider putting "Test" at the end of the
class name.

> public ser(String name) {
> super(name)
> }

This constructor is not needed in JUnit 3.8+

> public void testProgramStarted(){
>
> rtime = Runtime.getRuntime();
> Process child = rtime.exec(“/bin”);
>
>
> BufferedWriter outCommand = new BufferedWriter(new
> OutputStreamWriter(child.getOutputStream()));
> outCommand.writeLine(“start”);
> outCommand.flush();
> }

> public static void main(String[] args)
> {
> ser s= new ser();
> s.stProgramStarted();
>
> }

Here you are not using JUnit at all! You are, instead, just creating the
class and invoking testProgramStarted() like any other plain Java
application. Remove this main() method and run the test this way:

java -cp junit.jar;<your class files> junit.textui.TestRunner ser

I hope this clears some things up.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
